posts.cooked: Order the messages in the order they were sent. Language is heavily context based thus any other order doesn’t make any sense.

messages times are changed in conversations sometimes like:

user1: message 10min

user1: message 2min

user1: message 10min

Disclaimer: I might be totally wrong with this one. I thought about the problem for a couple of days. Talked with a bunch of friends. This is what I came up with.

As far as I can tell these are some of the givings you have to deal with in an asynchronous world and can not be changed easily.

  1. Sent time given out by clients is unreliable. Whether the clock of the phone is wrong or simply a different timezone. You can not trust the phones timestamp.

  2. From my understanding the problem occurs when the sending device is unable to reach the server.
    Not when the server is unable to reach the receiving device (in that case ALL messages will just be delivered at a later state). Therefore contrary to my post before the receiving timestamp does not help at all.

But if this can not be solved at the phone nor at the server, how do we solve it?

For that we have to look at how messages are transmitted.

Signal Messenger

Private Group Messaging

One of the major features we introduced in the TextSecure v2 release was private group chat. We believe that group chat is an important feature for encrypted communications projects, so we wanted to try to summarize some of the existing work in this...

And although I’ll gladly admit I did not understand the most of it, I believe at the end of the day it comes down to this.
There is one message for each member in a group. Or at least a session for each member.

So when B,C and E get a message from A but D doesn’t. What went wrong?

It looks like the original messages from A to the server (with B, C, D and E as recipient) where cut of at some point due to cellular loss or something. And all messages went through, except the one for D.

From here it looks like group messages are delivered one after another.
First A. Complete? Good.
Then B. Complete? Good.
Then C. Complete? Good.
and so on.

If your cellular cuts off after A and B those will be delivered. But C and D will have to wait. Which is exactly the situation we are talking about in this thread.

By sending out messages in a queue like fashion you leave a big window for oppurtunity of failure.

Is it possible to strive for a “all or nothing” approach? For example by not sending out the complete message but only 99% of it. Repeat that for all messages. And when all messages are almost ready just send the remaining n*1% to the server.

Thereby you reduce the final amount of data to be transmitted to a bare minimum and therefore the window of possible failure as well.

  1. I hope this is clear.
  2. I hope this is correct.
    I hope you will point out if either 1. OR 2. is not true.

Thanks

From my understanding the problem occurs when the sending device is unable to reach the server.
Not when the server is unable to reach the receiving device (in that case ALL messages will just be delivered at a later state). Therefore contrary to my post before the receiving timestamp does not help at all.> Blockquotep does not help at all.

On a group discussion between A, B and C, where C is disconnected, C might still get the wrong order of conversation between A and B when he connects with the server. From your understanding (and also my expectation from the server), it shouldn’t happen, should it?

A simple solution could be to let the server act as the timestamper and wrap every message with an asymetrically encrypted time-stamp, where the time should be the time of his receipt (when the server received the message). This way, we do not have to send to each user an approximative context of each message, neither do we have to trust their clock.

rdm174:

A simple solution could be to let the server act as the timestamper and wrap every message with an asymetrically encrypted time-stamp, where the time should be the time of his receipt (when the server received the message).

The server already delivers messages in the order it received them, so I don’t think there’s a need to add additional server-side time stamps.

The client can only see the timestamp corresponding to the time the server sent the message batch to the client, am I correct? Per example, I can see that a whole conversation is stamped with “sent at 16:00”.

With the server reception time included, not only the client would have the correct order, but also a better estimation of the time passed between the messages. In my previous example, the messages should have spawn some hours, not a minute.

The server already delivers messages in an ordered fashion, so the client shouldn’t need any additional time stamps to display messages in the order the server received them. This is what the Signal Android client does, for example. Don’t know about the other clients.

posts.name: Nicolas Despres
posts.cooked:
Hello!

I think anon61161739 and codewing have both strong arguments.

When a person writes three messages “Hello”, “How are you?” and “Bye” in that order they have to be displayed in that order. Whether or not they might be interleaved with another person messages. Otherwise this lead to misunderstanding. This is a must have requirement.

So if the client received a bunch of messages like the following in this order (A and B are two different persons):

A: How is it going?
A: Hi!
B: Bye
A: Cheers
B: Hello
B: How are you?

IMHO, they should be displayed like this:

A: Hi!
A: How is it going?
B: Hello
A: Cheers
B: How are you?
B: Bye

Using sender’s timestamp to sort its messages is reliable even if its clock is not synchronized via NTP and whatever its time zone is. The only requirement is that its clock never goes backward which I think we can safely assume to be always true. For ordering it is enough.

For displaying the date along the message in the client, the sender should encode the timestamp in UTC. Then the receiver can convert it to its own time zone and display it. I think that should work quite fine. Most devices are synced via NTP nowadays and not doing anything for devices that are not should cause no harm to 90% of the users. Let’s first satisfy 90% of the users and then think about what to do for the others if they complain.

For “reply to” message you can just embed a link in the message that expand and display the message it replied to when you click on it.

Cheers,
Nico

posts.cooked:
I found this thread while searching for an answer on ordering, and I’d like to leave another use case example.

I use Signal for Android and many of my contacts do not, meaning I rely on SMS (and MMS for group chats). I have not seen issues with actual Signal messages being out of order (I do not use the desktop client currently). The case that greatly affects me was reported in this github issue mentioned in the original request.

Many times throughout the day I either lose cellular connection in the office, or my cellular data is turned off (no unlimited plan). When I finally enable data, or regain the cellular connection, sometimes I have to manually download the missed MMS messages. This is an awful experience for that conversation, since I may be 6 messages behind from multiple participants, and end up getting 3 in a row from one contact and another 3 from the other:

B: yeah really intense
B: i’m running to the store, should i pick anything up?
B: ok i probably won’t be back until 9
A: did you see the game last night?
A: milk and eggs
A: that works, thanks

Signal messages are received in order and sent in order, and when the client connects it should also be able to receive them in the same order. But SMS and MMS messages rely to a greater extent on the client being available, especially for manually retrying MMS downloads, which in turn dramatically affects the Received time.

I think one way to resolve this would be a settings toggle for “Order SMS/MMS messages by Sent time” if the use case should be limited to only “unreliable” delivery mechanisms. Or it could be a toggle that affects all message types equally.

Addressing the “unreliability” of the sender’s clock, I’ve recently noticed that iOS devices always seem to have their clocks ahead of my device by approximately 75 seconds. I just checked an SMS on my phone, and the Sent time is 11:36:50 am while received time is 11:35:30 am. This exceptional case could be handled by ordering the client’s Sent messages against the other messages’ Received time, but it does add another layer of complexity.

Last point. If a message is received later than intended and is placed higher in the conversation, the user may miss that message. In my opinion, the most consistent approach is to move the “# UNREAD MESSAGES” line above the message with the “earliest” timestamp (“earliest” depends on the user’s preference for ordering by Sent time or Received time). Another possibility would be to highlight a message if it was placed anywhere other than the last element in the list. Either way, I think that keeping the conversation in the intended conversational order will be the correct answer 90% of the time, especially if the user intentionally opted-in to that feature.

Edit 1: Slight reordering of example to make it more clear that the conversation is very out of order.
